drills.name: The Navy SEAL Breath
drills.description: Used by elite operatives to control heart rate under gunfire. Trains your body to stay calm when pressure would normally make you gasp or hold your breath.
drills.notes: Practice 5 rounds: 1. Sitting calmly. 2. During bodyweight exercises. 3. Right after sprints. Pro tip: Place a hand on your belly to ensure diaphragmatic breathing.

drills.name: Authority Reframe
drills.description: Transforms 'threat' into useful adrenaline by changing how you perceive judgment.
drills.notes: Before competitions: 1. Identify 1 authority who triggers nerves. 2. Visualize them as an 'energy source' rather than judge. 3. Say: 'Your attention fuels my focus.' Based on fMRI studies showing reframing reduces amygdala activation by 62%.

drills.name: The Decisive Playbook
drills.description: Pre-programmed responses to bypass hesitation in critical moments by scripting reactions to common pressure scenarios.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Write 3 scenarios + responses. 2) Review daily for 2 weeks. 3) Simulate with eyes closed. Elite: Add physical triggers (e.g., tapping wrist for each script).

drills.name: Freeze-Breaker Protocol
drills.description: Combines tactile and breathing cues to interrupt freezing during performance.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Practice in training. 2) Add mild stress (e.g., coach yelling). 3) Use in competition. Works by disrupting amygdala hijack via dual sensory input.

drills.name: Combat Breathing
drills.description: Navy SEAL-tested 4-second breath cycle to control heart rate and panic responses.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Seated. 2) During cooldowns. 3) Under physical stress. Elite: Add eye tracking (follow finger while breathing).

drills.name: The 10-Second Reset
drills.description: Rapid physiological reset using grounding techniques between plays/points.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Normal conditions. 2) Mild fatigue. 3) After mistakes. Based on sensory anchoring research.

drills.name: The Carrot/Stick Journal
drills.description: Links concrete rewards/consequences to training behaviors to strengthen motivation pathways.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Daily entries. 2) Public accountability. 3) Variable rewards. Elite: Tie to biometrics (e.g., HRV targets).

drills.name: Threat Reframe Drill
drills.description: Transforms perceived threats into competitive fuel through cognitive restructuring.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Identify threats. 2) Write reframes. 3) Simulate exposure. Uses fMRI-verified prefrontal override techniques.

drills.name: Clutch Simulation
drills.description: Recreates high-pressure scenarios in training to build neurological tolerance.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Low stakes. 2) Added consequences. 3) Live streaming. Elite: Add sleep deprivation.

drills.name: Error Eraser
drills.description: 90-second neural reset protocol to stop post-mistake spirals.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Physical gesture. 2) Add scent. 3) Full sequence. Disrupts error-detection loops via novel stimuli.

drills.name: Evidence Lockbox
drills.description: Physical/digital repository of past successes to combat self-doubt.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Collect evidence. 2) Weekly reviews. 3) Pre-competition rituals. Activates success neural networks.

drills.name: The Crowd Filter
drills.description: Trains selective attention in chaotic environments using graduated exposure.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) 20% volume. 2) 50%. 3) Full noise + distractions. Rewires auditory filtering.

drills.name: Fatigue Focus Drill
drills.description: Maintains concentration under exhaustion using targeted attentional shifts.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Fresh. 2) Post-training. 3) Sleep-deprived. Uses peripheral vision control.

drills.name: Emotional Detachment Protocol
drills.description: Develops non-reactive performance states through meta-awareness training.
drills.notes: Progression: 1) Identify triggers. 2) Label emotions. 3) Practice detachment. Based on mindfulness research.

drills.name: Flow State Trigger
drills.description: Activates 'stay loose' neural pathways through a 3-step physical ritual to prevent freezing under pressure.
drills.notes: When tension builds: 1. Full-body shakeout (3s). 2. Forced smile with exhale. 3. Explosive movement cue. Based on facial feedback research showing smiles reduce cortisol by 15%.

drills.name: Decisive Action Protocol
drills.description: Trains instinctive decision-making through time-constrained scenario drilling to eliminate hesitation.
drills.notes: Daily: 1. Watch competition footage. 2. Make call in under 0.5s. 3. Physically mimic action. Strengthens parietal-occipital predictive pathways.

drills.name: The Noise Filter
drills.description: Develops selective auditory attention to neutralize crowd/coach/opponent distractions.
drills.notes: 1. Identify essential sounds (coach's voice). 2. Assign unimportant noise a color. 3. Imagine pushing it away. Uses thalamic gating mechanisms.

drills.name: The Internal Referee
drills.description: Silences self-conflict through cognitive defusion techniques adapted from ACT therapy.
drills.notes: When doubting: 1. Label thoughts ('I'm having the thought that...'). 2. Thank your mind. 3. Return to breath. Reduces cognitive fusion by 40% in trials.

drills.name: Tactical Reset Matrix
drills.description: Speed-adjustable recovery protocol matching reset cadence to competition demands.
drills.notes: Choose reset speed: 1. Fast (3s power exhale). 2. Medium (5-5-5 breath). 3. Slow (4-6-8 sequence). Aligns with heart rate variability needs.

drills.name: Breath Signature Scan
drills.description: Diagnostic tool to identify and normalize breathing patterns under stress.
drills.notes: Post-exertion: 1. Observe natural breath for 1min. 2. Classify pattern. 3. Adjust toward 6 breaths/min. Enhances respiratory sinus arrhythmia coherence.

drills.name: Validation Detox
drills.description: Transforms external validation-seeking into self-referential motivation anchors.
drills.notes: Weekly: 1. List 3 personal success metrics. 2. Contrast with external opinions. 3. Create physical reminder (e.g., wristband). Targets ventral striatum reward pathways.

drills.name: The Arena Mindset
drills.description: Converts competitive motivation into physiological arousal regulation.
drills.notes: Pre-competition: 1. Watch footage of iconic competitors. 2. Physical power pose. 3. Repeat: 'This is my arena'. Boosts testosterone by 20% in studies.

drills.name: The Phoenix Protocol
drills.description: Structured comeback sequence for athletes who shutdown after errors.
drills.notes: Post-error: 1. Symbolic gesture (wipe slate). 2. Reset breath (4-4-6). 3. First aggressive action. Reignites competitive drive via noradrenaline modulation.

drills.name: The Confidence Switch
drills.description: Creates facility-independent confidence through embodied cognition techniques.
drills.notes: Daily: 1. Recall peak performance feeling. 2. Assign physical trigger (e.g., tapping collarbone). 3. Activate in new environments. Uses episodic memory neural networks.

drills.name: Audio Blackout Training
drills.description: Conditions athletes to perform instinctively when crowd/coach audio suddenly cuts out during critical moments.
drills.notes: During practice: 1. Randomly mute environment for 3-5s. 2. Athlete must complete pre-called action. 3. Gradually increase complexity. Mimics championship pressure moments.

drills.name: The Exposure Ladder
drills.description: Systematic exposure to feared scenarios to eliminate avoidant behaviors.
drills.notes: Weekly: 1. Identify avoided situations. 2. Gradual exposure starting at 30% intensity. 3. Reward engagement. Uses systematic desensitization.

drills.name: Compensation Calibrator
drills.description: Prevents overcorrection after mistakes through technical reset protocol.
drills.notes: Post-error: 1. Pause. 2. Perform 2 perfect reps at 50% speed. 3. Resume normal pace. Targets error-correction pathways.

drills.name: Judgment Firewall
drills.description: Blocks external criticism from impacting performance through cognitive filtering.
drills.notes: Pre-competition: 1. Write down feared judgments. 2. Physically discard paper. 3. Replace with personal standard. Leverages symbolic action research.

drills.name: The Fatigue Override
drills.description: Maintains decision quality under exhaustion through cognitive priming.
drills.notes: Post-training: 1. Ice face immersion (30s). 2. Pre-load 3 decisions. 3. Execute while exhausted. Boosts frontal lobe oxygenation.

drills.name: Coach Whisper Drill
drills.description: Trains selective focus on essential coach cues amidst chaos.
drills.notes: During scrimmages: 1. Coach gives occasional low-volume cues. 2. Athlete must identify/execute. 3. Gradually increase distractions. Sharpens auditory selective attention.

drills.name: Freeze Thaw Protocol
drills.description: Breaks performance-freezing through physiological resets.
drills.notes: When frozen: 1. Ice pack to neck (5s). 2. Shake out limbs. 3. Explosive first step. Triggers mammalian dive reflex.

drills.name: The Why Finder
drills.description: Identifies hidden motivation sources for athletes with unclear drivers.
drills.notes: For 7 days: 1. Log energy peaks during training. 2. Reverse-engineer triggers. 3. Create motivation 'menu'. Builds metacognitive awareness.

drills.name: Overthink Antidote
drills.description: Short-circuits analysis paralysis through time-constrained decisions.
drills.notes: Daily: 1. Review game footage. 2. Make call in <1s. 3. Physical mimicry. Strengthens instinctive decision pathways.

drills.name: Pressure Inoculation
drills.description: Rebuilds trust in clutch abilities through graduated exposure.
drills.notes: Weekly: 1. Simulate high-pressure scenarios. 2. Physical activation ritual. 3. Post-success anchoring. Rewires threat appraisal.

drills.name: The Hesitation Killer
drills.description: Pre-programmed action triggers to eliminate delays in decision-making during critical moments.
drills.notes: When uncertain: 1. Snap fingers. 2. Say cue word. 3. Commit to first instinct. Trains sub-second decision latency.

drills.name: Demand Dominance Drill
drills.description: Builds assertive ball/shot demand behavior in pressure situations.
drills.notes: Daily: 1. Visualize demanding action in key moments. 2. Physical claiming gesture (e.g., hand clap). 3. Verbal call for ball/shot. Rewards neural pathways for assertive behavior.

drills.name: The Mental Loop Breaker
drills.description: Physical reset protocol to stop repetitive mistake replay in the mind.
drills.notes: After error: 1. Wiping motion across forehead. 2. Sharp exhale. 3. Immediate positive action. Disrupts default mode network looping.

drills.name: Re-Engagement Protocol
drills.description: Systematic method to overcome post-mistake withdrawal or disengagement.
drills.notes: When withdrawing: 1. Force eye contact with coach/teammate. 2. Physical touch (e.g., tap chest). 3. Immediate participation in next play. Uses social bonding oxytocin response.

drills.name: Coach Signal Focus
drills.description: Trains selective attention to maintain performance despite coach instructions.
drills.notes: During drills: 1. Identify essential coach cues. 2. Assign non-essential talk a color. 3. Mentally 'delete' irrelevant input. Strengthens auditory selective attention.

drills.name: Social Focus Armor
drills.description: Develops immunity to teammate/opponent distractions through exposure training.
drills.notes: Weekly: 1. Train with deliberate provocations. 2. Maintain 'bubble' focus. 3. Reward sustained attention. Uses habituation neuroscience principles.

drills.name: Gym-to-Game Bridge
drills.description: Transfers training confidence to competition through environmental anchoring.
drills.notes: Pre-competition: 1. Wear training gear item. 2. Recreate training warmup. 3. Recall gym successes. Creates neural environment familiarity.

drills.name: Control Converter
drills.description: Transforms need for control into adaptive focus points during performance.
drills.notes: Identify: 1. Three controllable factors (e.g., breathing). 2. Three uncontrollables (e.g., ref calls). 3. Focus only on controllables. Reduces anxiety by 37% in studies.
